results.title: Australian [colour] diary. No. 002
results.brief_description: The magazine items featured include a look at a mobile kindergarten established in Canberra; new methods of whaling in a rapidly developing industry and Danish gymnasts captivating Australian audiences with their folk-dancing and gymnastics.

results.title: Australia: the encounter
results.brief_description:
Recounts the story of Matthew Flinder’s circumnavigation around Australia, his trials across the Tasman, involvement with the Nagarrindjeri tribe and his encounters with a French explorer. The Aboriginal people clash with these “white ghosts”. On his way home to England, Flinders is imprisoned in Mauritius and his prized cat, Trim is killed. A decade later, Flinders returns home to his family. Meanwhile, the violence upon Aboriginal sacred lands continues.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Australia: secrets of the land down under
results.creator_credit: Chip Duncan and International Video Network
results.brief_description: Begin your tour of vast Australia in Sydney, then head to the Blue Mountains, where the squawks of wild parrots are drowned out by Wentworth Falls. Visit Canberra the federal capital, Melbourne, the nation’s financial and cultural centre and then travel across the continent to Perth. Watch the blazing sun paint Ayer’s Rock blood red and complete your visit with stops at Brisbane and the Great Barrier Reef.

results.title: Australia: room down under
results.creator_credit: Westinghouse Broadcasting Company for Intertel and Dan Klugherz
results.brief_description: This American assessment of Australia gives special attention to our migrant programme and the subtle ways immigrants are changing Australia’s way of life. The question of the White Australia Policy, the contrasts of great cities and desolate interior, and to the arts and sports. Australia as it appears to a newcomer is seen through the impressions of a migrant girl in her unrehearsed discussions with her Australian boyfriend. Film includes interviews with swimming coach Don Talbot, filmmaker Tim Burstall.

results.title: Australia: per forza e per amore
results.brief_description: Giovanni was working on an olive farm as a teenager when he was suddenly called home - he was leaving for Australia in 2 hours! In this story he tells of his life since that day and how he became a political figure in his new homeland. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: Australia: eye of the storm
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Channel 4, Telcast International, Granada Media, Jeni Clevers, Klaus Toft, Ashley Smith and Mark Lamble
results.brief_description: This four part series describes the powerful climate systems that batter Australia and how they affect it’s weather, wildlife and people. Using state-of-the-art cinematography, computer graphics and satellite images, each program traces the development of one climactic force and explains how Australia’s plants and animals cope with these long-term weather events. Forces examined include: ‘La Nina’ (combination of torrential rainfall, cyclones and massive floods); ‘Southern Exposure’ (sudden storms from Antarctica and the Southern Ocean); ‘El Nino’ (droughts and bushfires from heat and lack of water) and ‘Monsoon’ (rainstorms and accompanying sea conditions). Also included in this video is a short program called ‘Stormchasers’ which looks at the making of the other four programs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Channel 4, Telcast International, Granada Media, Jeni Clevers, Klaus Toft, Ashley Smith and Mark Lamble

results.title: Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, ABC-TV (Australia), BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description: Art critic Robert Hughes considers his relationship to Australia, 35 years after leaving the country in this television documentary series. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia and explores contemporary Australian culture with an appreciation that only came after he was forced to question his mortality. Written by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Australia: a technological society?
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Focus Audio-Visual Services and Appleseed Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. This final episode examines the increasing impact of technology throughout all Australian industry. Increases in productivity are linked to the growing mechanisation of industries and a resultant change to traditional work practices. As a direct result of increased mechanisation, workers now need to retrain and be educated in using new technologies. Through interviews with employees and management the impact of technology on working life is discussed, as well as the effects technology will have on Australian society in the future.
